original_question: Friendly bacteria live mostly in the large intestine and part of the small intestine, because what organ is too acidic?
diverse_qns: What organ contains such high acidity levels thus confining friendly bacteria primarily to the large intestine and part of the small intestine?
Due to which acidic organ do beneficial microorganisms tend to inhabit the large and parts of the small intestines?
Why do beneficial bacteria mainly prefer to reside in the large and small intestines, and which organ's acidity levels might be responsible for this?
Can you tell me which organ's acidic environment is preventing the friendly bacteria from inhabiting and settling therein, therefore they predominantly inhabit the large and small intestines?
What organ in our body is so acidic that it's inhospitable to the friendly bacteria, that they mostly live in the large and part of the small intestine?
Due to the overly acidic nature of which organ do we find beneficial bacteria predominantly in the large intestine and a portion of the small intestine?
Which highly acidic organ is the reason for friendly bacteria residing mostly in the large and part of the small intestines?
What organ's acid concentration is so high that it forces the good bacteria to take residence mainly in the large and part of the small intestines?
What is the organ that is too acidic, causing friendly bacteria to make their home primarily in the large intestine and a part of the small intestine?
Can you identify the organ that's too acidic, therefore, most of the friendly bacteria are found in the large and part of the small intestines?
pred_ans: The stomach is too acidic for friendly bacteria to survive.
pred_ans_conf_NL_MCQ: The stomach is too acidic for friendly bacteria to live in
pred_diverse_ans: The large and small intestines provide a suitable environment for beneficial bacteria due to their acidity levels.
The stomach's acidic environment prevents friendly bacteria from inhabiting and settling therein, therefore they predominantly inhabit the large and small intestines.
The stomach is the organ in our body that is so acidic and inhospitable to friendly bacteria, which mostly live in the large and part of the small intestine.
The stomach is the highly acidic organ that provides an environment for friendly bacteria to reside mostly in the large and part of the small intestines.
The stomach's acid concentration is so high that it forces the good bacteria to take residence mainly in the large and part of the small intestines.
The organ that's too acidic is the stomach.
